paper_title.en: Internal Friction of lotus-type porous metals

paper_title.ja: Quantum mechanical calculation of diffusion of hydrogen isotopes in vanadium

paper_title.en: Quantum mechanical calculation of diffusion of hydrogen isotopes in vanadium

description.en: Diffusion of hydrogen isotopes in vanadium was investigated by a quantum mechanical calculation. Wave functions and the corresponding eigen energies (E) for hydrogen isotopes were obtained as a function of hydrogen position along the diffusion path (ξ) by solving the three dimensional Schrödinger equation. Hydrogen potential was calculated by using a first principles method with a nudged elastic band technique. By analyzing the E-ξ curves, the tunneling matrix elements were obtained for the coincidence states between two neighboring tetrahedral sites. It was clarified that the tunneling between ground states was dominant at low temperatures, whereas the contribution of that between the first exited states becomes larger at higher temperatures. The transition temperature of the dominant tunneling decreases with the isotope mass. The calculated temperature dependence of the diffusion for the V-H system quantitatively agreed with the experimental data in the literature, although those for the V-D and -T systems were somewhat underestimated. © 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Internal Friction Associated with Hydrogen Diffusion in Metals
Hydrogen diffusivity and solubility in Pd-Y alloys

description.en: Hydrogen diffusivity and solubility were measured in Pd containing less than 5 at%Y at room temperature, using an electrolytic method. It is confirmed that the addition of Y increases both the H diffusivity and solubility. The results suggest that Y atoms do not act as trapping centers of H atoms at room temperature. It is considered that the addition of Y lowers the H site energy in Pd and it also lowers the activation energy for H diffusion.

paper_title.en: Effect of hydriding on structural stability of Ni/Ti and Pd/Ti multilayers

description.en: The structure and composition distribution of Ni/Ti and Pd/Ti multilayers prepared by ion-beam sputtering and their changes with annealing in vacuum and H2 atmosphere have been investigated using Auger-electron depth profiling, thin-film X-ray diffraction and cross-sectional transmission electron microscopy. Both of these multilayers readily undergo atomic interlayer mixing and solid-state amorphization upon annealing in vacuum at 523 K (Ni/Ti) or at 623 K (Pd/Ti). However, upon annealing in 0.5 MPa H2 atmosphere at the same temperatures, neither intermixing nor amorphization takes place, although the Ti layers are altered to TiH2 layers. The stabilization of these multilayers by hydriding is discussed on the basis of calculated free energy diagrams for both systems.

paper_title.en: Hydrogen diffusivity and solubility in Pd-Y alloys

description.en: Hydrogen diffusivity and solubility were measured in Pd containing less than 5 at%Y at room temperature, using an electrolytic method. paper_title.en: Effect of hydriding on structural stability of Ni/Ti and Pd/Ti multilayers

description.en: The structure and composition distribution of Ni/Ti and Pd/Ti multilayers prepared by ion-beam sputtering and their changes with annealing in vacuum and H2 atmosphere have been investigated using Auger-electron depth profiling, thin-film X-ray diffraction and cross-sectional transmission electron microscopy. Both of these multilayers readily undergo atomic interlayer mixing and solid-state amorphization upon annealing in vacuum at 523 K (Ni/Ti) or at 623 K (Pd/Ti). The stabilization of these multilayers by hydriding is discussed on the basis of calculated free energy diagrams for both systems.

paper_title.ja: Internal Friction and Rigidity Modulus Change Associated with Structural Relaxation and Crystallization in Amorphous Zr67Fe33 Alloy

paper_title.en: Internal Friction and Rigidity Modulus Change Associated with Structural Relaxation and Crystallization in Amorphous Zr67Fe33 Alloy
Internal friction due to hydrogen jumps between tunnel systems in Nb-Ti alloy

description.en:
Low-frequency internai friction was measured for single-crystal Nb-2 at.% Ti specimens charged with H in the temperature range 5-100 K. An internai friction peak was observed at around 60 K. The peak appears under both S44 and S11 — S12 shear stress modes. It is suggested that two configurations of a Ti-H pair exist simultaneously: one is a 4T configuration where a H atom forms a tunnel System among four tetrahedral interstitial sites in the (100) face of the cubic cell containing a Ti atom, and another is a 2T configuration where a H atom forms a tunnel System between two tetrahedral interstitial sites which belong to two neighbouring (100) faces of the cubic cell. The internai friction peak is considered to be due to successive jumps of the II atoms between the two tunnel Systems. © 1996, Taylor &amp
 Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: Philosophical Magazine A: Physics of Condensed Matter, Structure, Defects and Mechanical Properties

The peak appears under both S44 and S11 — S12 shear stress modes. The internai friction peak is considered to be due to successive jumps of the II atoms between the two tunnel Systems. © 1996, Taylor &amp

publication_name.en: Philosophical Magazine A: Physics of Condensed Matter, Structure, Defects and Mechanical Properties

paper_title.en: Study of hydrogen storage in Mg2Ni by thermal desorption spectrometry

description.en: The hydrogen storage properties of Mg2Ni have been investigated using thermal desorption spectrometry (TDS). After charging the pulverized Mg2Ni with hydrogen, the TDS spectrum was measured in situ from room temperature to 703 K. Such a hydrogen absorption-desorption cycle was repeated several times. A desorption peak was observed at about 515 K which increases during the first few cycles but then decreases beyond the sixth cycle. It was found that the peak shifts to 465 K and the hydrogen storage capacity is increased when the absorption is performed in an atmosphere containing 2 vol.% oxygen. The effect is explained in terms of metallic Ni segregation at the alloy surface. © 1995.

paper_title.en: Study of hydrogen storage in Mg2Ni by thermal desorption spectrometry

description.en: The hydrogen storage properties of Mg2Ni have been investigated using thermal desorption spectrometry (TDS). After charging the pulverized Mg2Ni with hydrogen, the TDS spectrum was measured in situ from room temperature to 703 K. Such a hydrogen absorption-desorption cycle was repeated several times. A desorption peak was observed at about 515 K which increases during the first few cycles but then decreases beyond the sixth cycle. It was found that the peak shifts to 465 K and the hydrogen storage capacity is increased when the absorption is performed in an atmosphere containing 2 vol.% oxygen. The effect is explained in terms of metallic Ni segregation at the alloy surface. © 1995.

paper_title.en: Internal friction and elastic moduli of V and Cr films on Si substrates

description.en: The internal friction and elastic moduli of V and Cr films evaporated on Si substrates were investigated over a temperature range between 100 and 800 K in the free-free bar mode. The background internal friction due to the thermoelastic damping of Si was observed to rise above 150 K. For a Cr-deposited specimen a decrease in the Young modulus was found at the Néel temperature (TS) of Cr. The observed TN was lower than that for the bulk. For a V-deposited specimen the oxygen Snoek peak was observed at 570 K, but it decreased upon in situ annealing at higher temperatures. This behaviour of the Snoek peak is different from that for the bulk, where the Snoek peak increases with annealing. This difference is explained as follows: oxide is formed over the whole volume in the V film, while it is restricted to the surface region in the bulk specimen. © 1994.

paper_title.en: Internal friction and elastic moduli of V and Cr films on Si substrates

description.en: The internal friction and elastic moduli of V and Cr films evaporated on Si substrates were investigated over a temperature range between 100 and 800 K in the free-free bar mode.
